item.title: Britannia Hospital
item.description: Great conception and surprising relevance. The scope is so broad it even includes midgets.

item.title: The White Bus
item.description: It’s a high-quality, disconnected kind of cinema.

item.title: O Lucky Man!
item.description: It feels to be an unusual kind of retro. It’s a range of different things, so it’s not obvious what to think or write about it. Those Brits - I can’t figure what’s the matter with them.

item.title: Birdman
item.description: It’s a bit like After Hours, it seems more realistic but makes less sense.

item.title: The Donner Party
item.description: The movie poster image looked so bad that I wanted to watch it. After watching it, I lost any appetite for making jokes. Anyway, it’s a must for those who appreciate certain other movie.

item.title: Gattaca
item.description: I’ve watched it from A Trip to the Moon perspective.

item.title: Blade Runner (Final cut)
item.description:
I’ve seen this already but the first watch is necessarily incomplete. The concept has a certain seemingly absurd unconstrained truth to it. There are also moments of meditation on different topics in between. I think I got so full an experience that I may just ignore the commentary and other materials.

Spoilers

Batty is a good chap in the end.

item.title: Dark City (Director's cut)
item.description: I was intrigued by the beginning. Then, in retrospect, the overall idea makes sense. So I see the point in the ending, also. I don’t follow games, but one could see how these ideas transfer well to VR at least.

item.title: If....
item.description: A lot of good points, need to see more by the director.

item.title: The Big Clock
item.description: It’s great. I may look into all the random leads at some point. But I’m not doing the third watch now just for that.

item.title: Paisà (1946)
item.description: Unnice movie with memorable scenes. Some are too on the surface, while others are buried.

item.title: The Bitter Tea of General Yen
item.description:
It was recommended by Coppola in an interview, so one can’t go wrong with it.

The Battle of Algiers

I’ve also watched The Battle of Algiers. It has memorable shots, but overall there is something dehumanizing about it. Whatever documentary and imaginative or technical value it has, I like another kind of East. And this is the relevance to The Bitter Tea of General Yen.

item.title: The Driver (1978)
item.description: I like that this was made after Le Samouraï and implied East vs West aspect here. I don’t think one can choose between movies, maybe they are funnier when considered in comparison.

item.title: The Thief (1952)
item.description: It’s good. Nice ordering here too.

item.title: Un Chien Andalou
item.description: Unspeakable of.

item.title: Ikiru
item.description:
I’ve watched both Ikiru and The Blob on the same day. And then finished it with Pee-wee’s Big Adventure. Now I’ll need to live with this, so I need to rethink this blog’s philosophy.

Maybe it will be ratings blog. So I’ll rate them.

  1. Ikiru goes first because rabbits can jump and they’d smash the competitors
  2. The Blob takes the second place because it destroys dinosaurs
  3. Pee-wee is the last because he was riding in the wrong direction

item.title: Metropolis
item.description: It produces good dreams. In a good way. Talking about analysis, it leaves so much to make sense of. Yet, counterintuitively, I’ve managed to find what I’d consider an insight on the M movie.

item.title: Dial M for Murder (3D)
item.description: Bad movie with good references. I love how things referred to range from the very exact to very hazy. It’s a must-rewatch movie, unforgettably so.

item.title: The Manchurian Candidate (1962)
item.description: I didn’t follow the last American political murder attempt, because I assume clueless psychos do the kind of thing. In the movie at least you know who the ultimate enemy is, and therefore you can have a great movie about it. But the modern stuff is like entropy - I didn’t care to watch it, however real it was. So it should be my comfort movie about good old days.

item.title: X4
item.description:
I can’t afford proper helicopter simulator setup so I have been checking X4 space sim. Of course it gets disgusting pretty quickly but some aspects are interesting still.

One thing is that there is opponent type named “M” and the game pronounces that with metallic female voice at random points when it’s the closest next target to deal with. I can’t put my finger on what’s clearly the cause and what’s the consequence but I do get insights about the movie and I wanted to blame the game for the latest insight I got about the movie.

item.title: Dial M for Murder
item.description:
I’ve been watching some Hitchcock and I had to have a post about this movie. In my limited experience, I don’t see the director messing with the viewer and instead it’s very classy cinema. The problem is that there is nothing to add in terms of arbitrary writing.

The movie is cold and smart, but after M proper I’ve enjoyed To Catch a Thief more. Also a movie set in France must be superior a priori. So I must forget the title and write something about To Catch a Thief instead.

item.title: M
item.description:
Among other qualities the movie attempts to understand the relevant pathology of its time at the risk of making sense of it. I like how The Shining overlaps with the movie in terms of the toolbox used; Taxi Driver is an interesting tangent for the time where M kind of killer is no longer somebody exceptional.

Among the pathologies it seems newspapers were a mess at the time, so maybe diving into that is a lead to have some understanding of the movie context. But then modern media context is unlikely to be healthier.

item.title: American Zoetrope
item.description: Zoetrope is a nice metaphor for good cinema, because the viewer does not see 90% of things at any point in time. I’ve watched the Apocalypse Now workprint and have gotten another glimpse at another fascinating angle of the project. Fuck, it’s good.

item.title: Throne of Blood
item.description:
One characteristic childhood memory I have is, when I asked why Chinese have narrow eyes, I was told that because they are smart, so I started to walk around and operate with my eyes as closest as possible.

I think some far eastern, concise, ambiguous/imaginative, probably explicitly wisdom/educational stories impressed me at some point.

Throne of Blood, even if it is based on Shakespeare seems to be distilled in that minimalistic style. Even black and white format supports the austerity.

item.title: Rashomon
item.description: For whatever reason my headset decided to play it at the half-speed. I thought that timing goes wrong but didn’t care to check properly so I thought it was a director’s style decision to make it that way. The sound is very unusual, I don’t think I’m going to watch this movie normally after that experience. And it fits the beginning so much, so I fell in love with the movie right away.

item.title: Journalism
item.description:
I’ve consciously watched Apocalypse Now three times. First was the movie, then the documentary at some point, then later the movie with the director’s commentary audio track. These are three different lenses on the same project.

In the commentary track the director mentions that the journalist character was also inspired by a Russian from the source book. I’ve thought it’s funny that I’m also Russian and I tend to peddle gateway drugs into arts/cinema. So I need to try to avoid it looking the same way.

item.title: Vortex Ring State
item.description:
I’ve been checking some aviation simulators. The gateway drug was the free(ish) Falcon BMS with its strong focus on F-16. Then Huey helicopter model in DCS got me intrigued. So I’ve been trying it for a couple of days. In helicopters that are not overly automated, stability is not granted at all and requires special attention from the pilot. That makes them interesting.

Flying over the Cold War Berlin made some Der Himmel über Berlin associations. Considering the technicalities of the flight I saw Apocalypse Now, too. Mixing technology and the arts, I wanted to bring odd can of soup painting into the post but maybe I was just hungry.

item.title: Birdman of Alcatraz
item.description: It hits some big targets with one rock. Retro feel and maybe different pacing/dialog is not unexpected for such isolation.

item.title: Mr. Scorsese
item.description:
Good spirited creative documentary. I love how The Passion of the Christ received newly decorated framing in the third episode. New York, New York that I haven’t seen yet that caught my attention; it must be the hight of something. It would be one of the spiritual movies also if, say, corruption shows, but not by director’s design.

Of course the bigger picture is that back in the day it was about criminal families, but these days it’s about these conglomerates like Wall Street, Hollywood, and their big bosses there.

item.title: Seven Samurai
item.description:
After finishing the movie, I saw a dream resembling Wolf of Wall Street but with a limited palette, and it was unclear who was more high - the main characters or the more normal people around.

My take is that the movie is high. You can see they had fun doing it. Also it has wisdom elements and construction so I did the second watch/scroll to refine the details there. In that lane the movie is a potent meditation on human character traits and human action in abstract.

item.title: Hereditary (rewatch)
item.description: Here when it gets closer to winter small birds come around and periodically knock into windows. They can even destroy mosquito nets if humans refuse to feed them. As I recall farmers started feeding the population so they clean the trees but now part of the contract between the species is that humans feed them during the winter. So while meeting the obligation and observing birds I got some ideas and decided to rewatch Hereditary.

item.title: The Killers
item.description:
1946

I can’t say anything specific. Just a good black-and-white movie.

1964

One criticism not of the movie but of the context of overproduction of trashy content in our time is that the format of this movie is so overused by the cheapest series, games and whatnot. So it became inherently spoiled by seeming predictable.

It’s the right decision to watch these in the chronological order, it plays out meaningfully. Interestingly this colored movie seems more visibly retro to me than the black-and-white one. I like how Reagan playing a villain in the working class people’s movie implies historical irony.

item.title: Twin Peaks
item.description:
The name of the show felt interesting, so I’ve rewatched the first season. Also I had the preconception that it should be the predecessor of The Shining. I guess one being the abstract modern horror and another being so retro and provincial made the illusion. My verdict is that it’s interestingly made but unconceptual as it is, so the peak is not even in the ballpark.

It does not mean the viewer can’t find interesting allusions or some detachment in the show’s atmosphere. At one point I felt that atmosphere could have certain value as if TV turned into a fireplace and people watching it could have some common mystery experience.

item.title: The Wages of Fear (1953)
item.description:
Un (process spoilers)

To me, it’s some advanced horror with a timer. As with fireworks, in case of accidental explosion, a small, controlled follow-up explosion may calm the nerves. This means rewatching the first half of it now (the next day) and then whether/how/when to watch the Sorcerer movie is some question down the line.

Deux (concept spoilers)

  • Not an intentful reference but SOC in Russian translation sounds directly like juice.
  • I always like to encounter translations into Russian from European languages that do have more juice than often dry English subs. In this case only one tranlation got it but multiple other translations and the English subs I’ve seen just failed to get Donald Duck reference.
  • One question to AI and this good reference comes out: de leurs épées, ils forgeront des socs.

Second half-watch worked well.

item.title: Beat the Devil
item.description: Maybe I should flood this blog with this kind. Just don’t know what to write about them.

item.title: Antichrist
item.description:
Adult movie. I assume people with heart conditions don’t watch horror, especially this one. Watching this should be an insurance violation.

Overall it’s transparent but some aspects are left for delayed appreciation. These are the animals and the physicality. Yet solving such things calls for rewatching it and while the movie is alike to desecration, rewatching it is also in its own way. And I think I got the general point.

item.title: The Small Back Room
item.description:
Good The Archers movie with:

  • director’s games and expressionism influence
  • conception is powerful, whether it is from the book or if it was edited
  • ethical (social) aspect, that is not losing relevance

item.title: Hell's Angels
item.description: I love how Howard Hughes had reach over the Atlantic before getting the routes.

item.title: Jet Set
item.description:
Arts offer spectacular victories. It seems taking them personally is what produces the antagonist in Apocalypse Now.

I think the victory belongs to the human spirit under constraint. Then it’s about choosing a new constraint and a new target.

So there is a selflessness aspect but not any kind of self-indulgent version.

item.title: Hearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker's Apocalypse
item.description: Unseparable from the movie itself experience.

item.title: Once Upon a Time in the West
item.description:
I’ve watched it with unmeant overtones around the early Claudia Cardinale scenes. So the timing of watching was strange, and it was the first watch.

The Western genre seems to offer directness but not at the cost of imagination, wit, and humor. Of course there is also the metaphysics of the time, the place, and the character. But I like to see/infer actual human experience that is packed into the artifact of cinema. And given the ambiguity of the medium, it seems to be delivered relatively directly.

item.title: Despair (1978)
item.description: Nice depth of moral decay; perhaps inimitable.

item.title: Accident (1967)
item.description: Brits having fun at the viewers’ expense. Good cinema.

item.title: Monsieur Hire
item.description: On one hand it’s entertaining because it’s visually suggestive and referential and it’s both obvious and not forced seemingly; so there is perceived simplicity. On another hand, there are strong reasons for confusion about what’s going to happen. Given additional hand, I like the funny point at the end, almost a geometrical point about perpendicular lines not crossing in 3D space. Also given added note from a shoe, the viwer must be the biggest fool in this.

item.title: Monsieur Verdoux
item.description:
Lasso him.

Good movie. It’s funny how I slipped from horrors into Monsieur movies.

item.title: Monsieur Klein
item.description:
Overall

Good style cinema, something I’d rewatch, the movie almost gives you instructions on how to watch it.

These days my challenge with good cinema is to not get captured by the world of it but try to have parallel attention to technical aspects of the work. I feel If I can keep attention to technical, there is a general value to be realised.

Identity

The general point is that the protagonist has plenty of shallow, caricatured aspects of identity. And maybe there are deeper and higher aspects that can be seen.

item.title: Fidelio
item.description:
Whatever random public wrongly feels about the movie, it really represents the director’s fidelity to the arts. I expect to get around the 4K and have a blast closer to the new year.

The used cover art is on the disgusting side from the point of view above. But it’s what you would expect from a jealous wife.

item.title: Herzog Blaubarts Burg
item.description:
I only watched the English version now. It’s low budget project but I felt that Hein Heckroth’s involvement was a sufficient reason to check it. And it delivers effectively at times. I say it delivers right away early on even before saying a word.

Another point is that it could cast some more light on Peeping Tom main character. And yes, there is a match.

But overall I’m not conclusive yet. I’d need to re-check Peeping Tom and German version first because right now the subject feels alien to me for unknown reson.

item.title: Greed (1924)
item.description:
Good stuff, I enjoyed the mixed medium of silent cinema and plain photography. It’s one of the complex pictures with funny visual language all over and even having interactivity. It took me some time to finish that 4 hour watch.

UPD: of course my favorite impression is the theatricality of it.

item.title: The Servant
item.description: Top-tier cinema.

item.title: Hugo
item.description:
Dreamy pace and enjoyable 3D experience.

I think it’s peak 3D experience – it’s high quality and balanced even with certain sadness/nostalgia/emotion overarching mood. Conceptually it’s a gift of perspective at the cinema medium.

After Hugo and A Trip to the Moon I checked some books and got some cinema-related impossible dreams. It’s proof of magic there.

item.title: The Night of the Hunter
item.description:
There is something unique about the movie – probably all the madmen around, making the antagonist to look very fitting if not comparatively normal. It’s comparatively light movie since it does not ask for the second watch unlike some other movie.

Black and white medium has it’s magics. It’s the same point as the other movie has via-negativa: about simplicity and enjoying the time together.

item.title: Gravity 3D
item.description:
I can’t take it seriously for a minute, so I watched it with considerable scrolling. I see it as a screwed take on Space Odyssey by a Mexican director targeting Asian market, with an unstable long-legged female protagonist doing panting and screaming anime-style half of the movie.

It’s a funny thing to scroll through with that perspective in mind. I wasn’t too impressed by the 3D conversion, but it adds some reflection effects here and there.

item.title: The Wolf of Wall Street
item.description: Least depressing movie with most stimulants consumed. Yet it’s not unconceptual and fits the bill just enough to keep things light.

item.title: The Aviator
item.description: A scar and an ethos/spiritual statement.

item.title: After Hours
item.description: The most sane arts movie and the only sharks movie that matters.

item.title: Torque
item.description:
TLDR

Digging maze vs actually solving.

What’s missing

The original Avocaat Party post was written on the spot and was not as analytical but more descriptive. Also I didn’t understand the implications of it anyway. So here, I try to integrate my understanding concisely.

Correction

If Rosemary’s Baby gives you a stab, digging into The Shining will stab you and then rotate the knife inside. Seven months on the wagon, I think I got back to the starting point.

item.title: The Phantom of Liberty
item.description: To rehabilitate after The Shining closet drinking business, I’ll sit out such cinema in favor of a lighter diet of movies like this one.
